instruction: A helpful writing exercise is writing a story without using adjectives or adverbs. This will help you learn to use other words and phrases to describe what you are trying to say. Here are some examples:
output:
This is a funny story. (adjective)
The story made me laugh. (adverb)
In this story, I will tell you about something that happened to me on my way home from work yesterday. (introductory phrase)
I was walking down the street when suddenly, I saw a dog running towards me. (verb)
The dog had a big smile on its face and it was wagging its tail happily. (verb + adjective)
As I got closer to the dog, I noticed that it was wearing a cute little hat. (adjective)
The dog then jumped up and licked my face before running off down the street. (verb)
As I stood there, dumbfounded by what had just happened, I realized that the dog must have belonged to one of the nearby houses. (conclusion)

Finally, the questioner should assess the candidate's ability to communicate findings and insights from R analysis, both verbally and in writing.

instruction:
Write a simple guide for uploading the bibliography database
 on Overleaf.
output:
Bibliography Database Upload Instructions
===============================
If you are using Overleaf to collaborate on a paper that requires a bibliography database, and you have not yet done so, please visit the following link to upload your database: 
https://www.overleaf.com/bibliography_databases
There are three ways to add a new database to your Overleaf account: via BibTeX, via an external URL or by manually adding records. 
1. Add your database via BibTeX: If your references are in a BibTeX format, you can upload your .bib file and Overleaf will automatically convert it into a suitable reference format for your chosen citation style. 
2. Add your database via an external link: If your references are stored in another format (e.g., EndNote or Procite), you can upload your reference library as an XML or JSON file. In this case, you will need to choose your desired citation style when uploading the file. 
3. Manually add your references: If you prefer to add references one-by-one, you can do so by clicking "Add References" in the upper-left corner of Overleaf's editor. This will allow you to search for and add records from the Overleaf database as well as those added by your co-authors.

instruction: Using the provided topic as a starting point, brainstorm ideas for videos that can be made about it on YouTube.
input: In spite of the fact that procrastination feels bad to you, why do you do it?
output:
Depression and anxiety can make it harder to get things done on time. If you have either of these conditions, you might feel more comfortable avoiding tasks that require a lot of focus or energy. This is especially true for tasks that seem overwhelming or unimportant. When you procrastinate, your stress levels will likely rise as you get closer to the deadline. You may feel like you’re in a constant state of crisis as the due date approaches.
After you complete your tasks, you may feel a sense of relief—but it won’t last long. You’ll probably start feeling anxious again once the next set of tasks come due. Prolonged procrastination can lead to burnout .
It feels good to cross things off your to-do list, so why not just do them right away? There are a few reasons why putting things off might feel better in the moment.
You might feel like you don’t have enough time to do everything you want to do. If this is the case, you might be tempted to skip tasks that you don’t think are important. By doing this, you can conserve your energy for the things you really care about.
Procrastination can also be a coping mechanism . If you tend to put things off, you might be using procrastination to avoid dealing with other issues in your life. For example, you might procrastinate on finishing a work project because you’re having a hard time at home. Procrastinating on your work might give you a temporary sense of relief that allows you to cope with your personal problems.
Some people use procrastination as a form of self-control . This means that they only do the tasks they really want to do. They might delay less enjoyable tasks until they absolutely have to do them.

instruction: Write a step-by-step guide for resolving GitHub merge conflicts.
output:
Step 1: Open the conflicted file in your favorite text editor.
Step 2: Look for and review changes made by both branches.
Step 3: Identify which changes you want to keep and which changes you want to discard.
Step 4: Resolve the merge conflict by choosing a resolution method.
Step 5: If necessary, apply any necessary undo operations to ensure your local changes are intact.
Step 6: Add any necessary context or explanations in the comment section of the merged file.
Step 7: Commit your changes and push them to the remote repository.
Step 8: Merge the pull request if applicable.

instruction: Write a short analysis of the cinematography in the movie.
input: Dead Poets Society
output:
is a movie that showcases the power of creativity and individuality. The cinematography in the film captures the beauty and complexity of these themes by using a combination of lighting, camera angles, and color schemes.
The film's use of lighting is particularly noteworthy. Many scenes are lit with warm, earthy tones, creating a cozy atmosphere that contrasts with the more somber moments. For example, the classroom scenes are often lit with a yellowish glow, while outdoor scenes tend to be brighter and more colorful. This contrast emphasizes the importance of escaping the confines of the classroom and exploring the world outside.
The camera angles also play an important role in conveying the film's themes. Shots are often taken from above, looking down on the characters, which gives the film a sense of grandeur and authority. This technique is used most effectively in the final scene, where the students stand on their desks to recite their poem. The shot is from below, looking up at the students, giving the scene a sense of empowerment and hope.
Overall, the cinematography in Dead Poets Society is a masterful blend of lighting, camera angles, and color schemes that enhances the film's themes of creativity and individuality.

instruction: Please let me know your thoughts on the given place and why you think it deserves to be visited.
input: Barcelona, Spain
output:
: The city of Barcelona, also known as the capital of Catalonia, is one of the most visited cities in Spain. It is located on the northeastern coast of the Iberian Peninsula, by the Mediterranean Sea. With almost 1.6 million inhabitants within its administrative limits and a metropolitan area population of over 4 million, it is the second-most populous municipality in Spain and the thirteenth-most populous urban area in the European Union.
Reasons to Visit:
1. Architecture: Barcelona is famous for its modernist architecture, which was developed by Antoni Gaudi and other Catalan architects in the early 20th century. Some of the most famous landmarks in Barcelona are the Sagrada Familia, Park Guell, Casa Batllo, and La Pedrera.
2. Beaches: The city has several beaches along its coastline, including Barceloneta Beach, Bogatell Beach, and Mar Bella Beach. These beaches are popular tourist attractions and offer a variety of water activities such as swimming, sunbathing, and windsurfing.
3. Food and Drink: Barcelona is known for its delicious cuisine, especially its tapas bars and seafood restaurants. There are also many cafes, bars, and nightclubs throughout the city that offer great food and drinks.
4. Museums: Barcelona has several world-class museums, including the Picasso Museum, the Museum of Contemporary Art, and the Fundació Joan Miró. These museums showcase some of the finest art, sculpture, and other cultural treasures from around the world.
5. Shopping: Barcelona is a shopper's paradise with its many boutiques, markets, and malls. The most famous shopping district is the Rambla

instruction: Make a questionnaire to help hotel guests write hotel reviews.
output:
Third-party review websites have fundamentally changed the way consumers research and choose hotels. While TripAdvisor’s popularity as a hotel review site has waned slightly over the years, other sites like Yelp, Google, Booking.com, Expedia and Facebook have become more and more important for travelers researching their next hotel stay.
If your guests are leaving you reviews on these sites, you want to make sure they are positive. For this reason, we recommend creating customized questionnaires for your guests to fill out at the end of their stay. These questionnaires will help you collect useful information about their experience that can be used to improve future guest experiences and respond to negative reviews.
The most useful information you can get from your guests is why they chose your hotel (location, price or brand affiliation) and how likely they are to return or recommend your hotel to friends and family. Here are some more questions you might want to ask your guests:
1. How did you hear about us?
2. What was your overall experience with our hotel?
3. Was our location convenient for your needs?
4. Were our check-in/check-out times convenient for your schedule?
5. Did you find our staff friendly and helpful?
6. Were our room types suitable for your needs?
7. Did our amenities meet your expectations?
8. How would you rate the cleanliness and condition of your accommodations?
9. How would you rate the condition of common areas in our hotel?
10. How would you rate the WiFi quality and speed in your room and public spaces?
11. Did you enjoy your meals at our restaurant(s)? If so, what did you like best?
12. Did you use our spa or fitness center? If so, how was your experience?

1. New England - Fall foliage is at its peak in New England in November. You can take a drive along the New England coastal scenic byway and enjoy the beautiful fall colors.
2. California - November is also a great time to visit California. You can go wine tasting in Napa Valley, go skiing in Lake Tahoe, or visit San Francisco which has mild weather in November.
3. Arizona - November is a great time to visit Arizona. You can go hiking in the Grand Canyon, see the changing leaves in Sedona, or visit Phoenix which has mild weather in November.
4. Florida - November is a transitional month in Florida. You can go to Disney World or visit other theme parks which have shorter lines than during the summer. You can also go to the beach and enjoy the warm weather.
5. Hawaii - November is the beginning of the winter season in Hawaii. You can go surfing, snorkeling, or visit volcanic sites like Haleakala National Park.
So, there you have it! These are some of the top places to visit in November in the US. Whether you're looking for fall foliage, warm weather, or theme park fun, there's something for everyone in the US in November.

instruction: Provide a Java solution to the following problem.
input:
Given an integer n, return true if it is a power of three. Otherwise, return false.
An integer n is a power of three, if there exists an integer x such that n == 3^x.

Example 1:
In: n = 27
Out: true
Explanation: 27 = 3^3

Example 2:
In: n = 0
Out: false
Explanation: There is no x where 3^x = 0.

Example 3:
In: n = -1
Out: false
Explanation: There is no x where 3x = (-1).
 
Constraints:
-231 <= n <= 231 - 1
Follow up: Could you solve it without loops/recursion?

instruction: You are given a programming problem and its implementation. Analyze the problem and implementation and explain the algorithm and approach used to solve the problem.
input:
Table: Person
| Column Name | Type     |
| personId          | int         |
| lastName         | varchar |
| firstName         | varchar |
personId is the primary key column for this table.
This table contains information about the ID of some persons and their first and last names.
Table: Address
| Column Name | Type     |
| addressId        | int         |
| personId          | int         |
| city                   | varchar|
| state                | varchar |
addressId is the primary key column for this table.
Each row of this table contains information about the city and state of one person with ID = PersonId.
Write an SQL query to report the first name, last name, city, and state of each person in the Person table. If the address of a personId is not present in the Address table, report null instead.
Return the result table in any order.
Implementation:
select FirstName, LastName, City, State
from Person left join Address
on Person.PersonId = Address.PersonId
;
output: This implementation uses a left join to combine the Person and Address tables. The result table includes all records from the Person table, plus any matching records from the Address table. Null values are returned for City and State if there is no corresponding record in the Address table for that person.

instruction: Summarize the article you have been given in a brief manner.
input:
Mathematics and art are related in a variety of ways. Mathematics has itself been described as an art motivated by beauty. Mathematics can be discerned in arts such as music, dance, painting, architecture, sculpture, and textiles. This article focuses, however, on mathematics in the visual arts.
Mathematics and art have a long historical relationship. Artists have used mathematics since the 4th century BC when the Greek sculptor Polykleitos wrote his Canon, prescribing proportions conjectured to have been based on the ratio 1:√2 for the ideal male nude. Persistent popular claims have been made for the use of the golden ratio in ancient art and architecture, without reliable evidence. In the Italian Renaissance, Luca Pacioli wrote the influential treatise De divina proportione (1509), illustrated with woodcuts by Leonardo da Vinci, on the use of the golden ratio in art. Another Italian painter, Piero della Francesca, developed Euclid's ideas on perspective in treatises such as De Prospectiva Pingendi, and in his paintings. The engraver Albrecht Dürer made many references to mathematics in his work Melencolia I. In modern times, the graphic artist M. C. Escher made intensive use of tessellation and hyperbolic geometry, with the help of the mathematician H. S. M. Coxeter, while the De Stijl movement led by Theo van Doesburg and Piet Mondrian explicitly embraced geometrical forms. Mathematics has inspired textile arts such as quilting, knitting, cross-stitch, crochet, embroidery, weaving, Turkish and other carpet-making, as well as kilim. In Islamic art, symmetries are evident in forms as varied as Persian girih and Moroccan zellige tilework, Mughal jali pierced stone screens, and widespread muqarnas vaulting.
output:
In Indian art, the mathematics of symmetry has been used since antiquity in the forms of the temple and its sculptural forms.
Three-dimensional art draws on geometry for its composition. Mathematics is central to computer graphics and animation, where it may be described as "the study of shape change". Geometry underlies the abstraction of mathematical modelling languages such as B-Spline. The use of dynamic symmetries in computer generated art has been explored by Diana Thompson. Mathematics has also inspired some experimental musical instruments, such as the Symphicon.

instruction: Improve the article using your knowledge of the topic in order to make it more informative.
input: The "fair trade" movement, also known as the "trade justice" movement, promotes the use of labour, environmental and social standards for the production of commodities, particularly those exported from the Third and Second Worlds to the First World. Such ideas have also sparked a debate on whether trade itself should be codified as a human right.
output:
Proponents argue that the current international trading system is unjust and promotes the exploitation of workers in poorer countries by corporations in richer countries.
The fair trade movement has its roots in the development of co-operative movements among European farmers in the late 19th century, who sought better prices for their crops and protested against the high commission paid to middlemen. It took a major step forward during the 1960s and 1970s as organizations such as Oxfam, Traidcraft and the British Fair Trade Association began marketing handicrafts made in developing nations to consumers in Europe and North America. Since then, fair trade has grown from a niche market to an international social movement with annual revenue of $4.5 billion (£2.7 billion) in 2013.
Through a number of instruments, fair trade certification guarantees that producers receive a minimum price for their commodities and that they are paid a premium on top of that price. The premium can be used to invest in infrastructure, education, health care and other community projects. The fair trade movement also promotes environmentally sustainable practices and transparency in supply chains.

input: Steam Engine Using an Empty Beer Can
output:
This is an old idea that has been floating around the internet for a while. The concept is to use an empty beer can as a boiler and a tea light candle as the steam source. This project is intended as a simple demonstration of the principles of a steam engine, but be warned that this is not a toy and should be handled with care.
Materials needed:
- Empty beer can
- Tea light candle
- Drill or Dremel tool
- Files or sandpaper
Instructions:
1. Drill a hole in the top of the beer can big enough for the tea light wick to poke through. Make sure the hole is at the very bottom of the can where it will be submerged in water.
2. With the drill, make a small hole in the side of the can near the bottom. Be careful not to go all the way through. This will be the inlet for the water.
3. Place the beer can in a container filled with water and position the tea light so that it sits above the hole in the side of the can. Light the candle and let it melt some wax. As the wax melts, it will drop down into the boiler and act as a heat exchanger, transferring heat from the flame to the water.
4. File or sandpaper down the edges of the hole in the side of the can so that it is slightly smaller than the tea light wick. This will prevent air from leaking into the system and shutting down the engine.
5. Run your finger over the piston to smooth any bumps or rough spots.

instruction: Estimate the cost of supplies required to create the given project and calculate the total cost.
input:
DIY Water Chiller
Required items are: Ice-maker, Icebox/cooler, Temperature regulator, Aquarium pump x2, 12V power supply
output:
, Refrigeration oil, and Tubing.
Ice-maker: $30 for this style. It will make 1.5" x 12" x 12" ice cubes. It will be used to cool the refrigeration oil. The ice cubes will drop into a bin in the cooler.
Icebox/cooler: A large cooler that is at least 24" long x 12" wide x 18" high. It will be used to hold the tubing and keep it cool. It can be as large or small as you want.
Temperature regulator: A temperature regulator that goes down to 32F. This will control the temperature of the refrigeration oil.
Aquarium pump x2: You'll need two pumps, one to circulate water through the chiller and another to return it to the tank. Use aquarium pumps because they are small and powerful.
12V power supply: A 12V power supply with a cigarette lighter plug. This will power the pumps and regulator.
Refrigeration oil: You'll need about 1/2 cup of refrigeration oil. It should be PAG oil, not mineral oil. Amazon has it.
Tubing: You'll need about 20' of 3/8" ID tube. This will connect the ice-maker to the cooler and the cooler to the tank. Get silicone tubing, not plastic.
The costs don't include the cost of the project itself, just the materials needed to build the chiller.

instruction: Give me an idea of the mental exercises you do to inspire yourself.
output:
If you are working on a challenging project, the best way to overcome the mental blocks is to challenge your assumptions.
Step 1: Identify an assumption that is preventing you from making progress , e.g. “I’m not good enough” or “This is too hard”.
Step 2: Challenge the assumption by asking yourself how you know this assumption is true and what evidence do you have for it. E.g. I often tell myself that I’m not smart enough to learn new technologies like React. The truth is that I’m not an expert in React but I’ve built a few small applications using React and I’ve also mentored people who were brand new to React and have helped them become proficient developers. So I know that I am capable of learning new things and getting better at them with practice and help from others.
Step 3: Once you challenge an assumption, you usually realize that it is not as strong as you initially thought. If you can overcome one assumption, you can overcome others.

instruction: Describe how to prepare the given food in your own words. Note down the ingredients you will need and the steps you will take to prepare them.
input: Chewy Chocolate Chip Cookies
output:
(Vegan)
Ingredients:
- 1 cup almond flour
- 2/3 cups maple syrup
- 2 tsp baking soda
- 1 tsp salt
- 1/4 cup coconut oil, melted
- 1/4 cup unsweetened applesauce
- 2 tsp vanilla extract
- 1 1/2 cups water
- 1 1/2 cups semi-sweet chocolate chips
Instructions:
1. Preheat the oven to 350°F. Line a baking sheet with parchment paper.
2. In a medium bowl, whisk together almond flour, maple syrup, baking soda, and salt.
3. Melt the coconut oil in a small saucepan over low heat. When liquid, let cool for a few minutes.
4. Add the melted coconut oil, unsweetened applesauce, and vanilla extract to the dry ingredients. Mix until well combined.
5. In a separate bowl, whisk together the water and almond milk until combined.
6. Slowly add the wet ingredients to the dry ingredients and mix until just combined. Fold in the chocolate chips.
7. Using your hands, form the dough into small balls and place on the prepared baking sheet. Flatten each ball slightly with your hand.
8. Bake for 10-12 minutes or until golden brown around the edges. Let cool for a few minutes before transferring to a wire rack to cool completely.

nth term = a + (n-1)d
where a is the first term, d is the common difference, and n is the term number.

nth term = 5 + 4n - 1

instruction: Describe the content of the article in a brief manner.
input: A study published earlier this year by Zee and her team examined the role of light in sleep for healthy adults in their 20s. Sleeping for only one night with a dim light, such as a TV set with the sound off, raised the blood sugar and heart rate of the young people during the sleep lab experiment. An elevated heart rate at night has been shown in prior studies to be a risk factor for future heart disease and early death, while higher blood sugar levels are a sign of insulin resistance, which can ultimately lead to type 2 diabetes.
output:
The study is one of the first to show that light at night has biological effects, Zee said. The findings were reported in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.
“We found that just a dim nighttime light, which most people would consider very low level, is enough to have consequences on metabolism,” she said. “This is an important observation.”
Zee and her team cautioned in the report that their results do not prove that light at night causes health problems; more studies are needed to establish a link.
But the findings are consistent with past research about artificial light interfering with sleep quality, Zee said. She noted that some studies have found increased health risks associated with shift work, in which people routinely work at night or in the early morning.
The artificial light from TVs, computers, smart phones, LED lights, streetlights and other sources has become part of modern life. But it’s only been in the past few decades that electricity-powered lamps and windows have replaced traditional light sources like candles, campfires, kerosene lamps and fireplaces.
The study participants were 16 young adults aged 18 to 29 who spent two nights in a lab sleeping with no covers over their eyes. In one session, they slept with the lights off. In the other, they slept under a dim red lamp. Blood sugar and heart rate were measured during the day and night while the participants also wore monitors to record sleep patterns.
The researchers found that during the night with the dim light, the participants had higher blood sugar levels and slightly lower melatonin levels – a hormone that regulates sleep and waking hours – than when the lights were off.
A small increase in heart rate during the night doesn’t necessarily mean a person will develop heart

instruction: You need to come up with the names of some of the papers that relate to the paper you are given.
input: RoMQA: A Benchmark for Robust, Multi-evidence, Multi-answer Question Answering
output: The goal of this benchmark is to provide a test bed for comparing the performance of different question-answering systems on a large and diverse set of questions. The dataset consists of 17,796 questions asked by users on Yahoo Answers. For each question, we extract facetype, answertype, and questiontext features. We also extract multiple evidence passages for each answer. Each question has one or more correct answers provided as text snippets. To create the dataset, we used crowdsourcing as well as automated methods for extracting relevant information from Yahoo Answers pages. Our evaluation shows that most existing systems fail to achieve high accuracy on our benchmark. However, we find that combining multiple evidence passages with a neural network based model yields significant improvements in performance.

instruction: Regex is a set of characters that define a search pattern. This kind of pattern is usually used by string-searching algorithms to find or replace strings or to validate inputs. Convert the natural english text to regex.
input: Match a valid ip address
output:
with regex.


def is_valid_ip_address(ip):
    # https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_protocol_address#Validator
    regex = r'^(?:(?:25[0-5]|2[0-4][0-9]|[1-9][0-9]{2}|[1-9][0-9]{4})\.){3}(?:25[0-5]|2[0-4][0-9]|[1-9][0-9]{2}|[1-9][0-9]{4})$'

    return True if match else False

instruction: List some of the top real estate marketing words to add value to the listing and engage more potential buyers.
output:
We asked this question to some of the top real estate agents in the US and here are their answers.
1. Location – This is one of the most important words when selling a house, as it gives potential buyers an idea of where the house is located.
2. Price – This is another key word that can entice potential buyers to take a look at your listing. By including the price, you’re letting them know right away if the house is within their budget or not.
3. Square Footage – This is a crucial detail for buyers who are looking for a house with a certain amount of space.
4. Bedrooms and Bathrooms – These words indicate how many rooms and bathrooms the house has, which can help buyers determine if it’s the right size for them and their family.
5. Amenities – Whether it’s a pool, garage, or updated kitchen, these words let buyers know what features the house offers.
6. Updates – If there have been any recent updates or renovations to the house, be sure to include this information so buyers know the house is in good condition.
7. Neighborhood – Describe the neighborhood in a positive way, highlighting the amenities and attractions nearby.
8. View – If the house has a great view, make sure to mention it so buyers can imagine themselves enjoying it from their own future home.
9. Proximity – Let buyers know how close they will be to schools, shops, and other important places.
10. Storage – If the house has extra storage space, be sure to note it so buyers know they won’t have to worry about finding space for their belongings.
